full_summary:
### Shelburne Land Acquisition - Request for Proposals

The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) is pleased to invite proposals for the acquisition of a three to six-acre parcel of vacant land in the town of Shelburne, Nova Scotia. The land must be located within a ten-kilometer radius of Exit 26 on Highway 103 and have municipal services or the ability to obtain approved well and septic services.

### Key Requirements

*   Land size: 3 to 6 acres (1 to 1.6 hectares)
*   Arterial road frontage or confirmation of access availability
*   Preferred zoning: commercial, institutional, or industrial
*   Rectangular shape
*   Proximity to amenities such as service stations, financial institutions, and restaurants

### Mandatory Submission Requirements

Proposers must provide the following information:

*   A map showing the parcel's location
*   Site plan
*   Current zoning description
*   Utility services details
*   Statement on the ownership and rights to the land
*   Completed Phase I Site Assessment (if available)
*   Property Transfer Assessment Questionnaire

### Evaluation Criteria

Proposals will be evaluated based on the following criteria:

*   Land size and location
*   Availability of municipal services
*   Compliance with zoning regulations
*   Proximity to amenities
*   Overall value to the RCMP's operations

### Submission Instructions

Proposals must be submitted electronically to Glenda Mercer at [Glenda.Mercer@rcmp-grc.gc.ca](mailto:Glenda.Mercer@rcmp-grc.gc.ca) or by mail to:

Glenda Mercer  
 Assets and Procurement
Royal Canadian Mounted Police
80 Garland Avenue, Mailstop H-060
Dartmouth, NS B3B 0J8

### Deadlines

The submission deadline is July 3, 2024. The RCMP reserves the right to request additional information or clarification on any submission.

Contact Information

For further information, please contact Glenda Mercer at (902) 720-5372 or [Glenda.Mercer@rcmp-grc.gc.ca](mailto:Glenda.Mercer@rcmp-grc.gc.ca). 

Note that this is a Request for Proposals and not a tendering process. Proposers must delineate their experience, qualifications, and approach to meeting the requirements outlined in the proposal.

The RCMP looks forward to reviewing submissions and exploring options for this acquisition.
